facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 96 of 1957 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 96 of 1957. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated December 17, 1956 of Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 17, 1956, of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi in Civil Misc. No. 896-D

facts.text: High Court case Civil Misc. No. 896-D of 1956 arising out of judgment dated November 1, 1956 of Commercial Subordinate Judge, Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: Circuit Bench  at Delhi in Civil Misc. No. 896-D of 1956, arising out of the judgment and order dated November 1, 1956, of the Court of Commercial Subordinate Judge, Delhi

facts.text: Suit No. 264 of 1956 filed under Order XXXVII CPC in Court of Commercial Subordinate Judge, Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: order dated November 1, 1956, of the Court of Commercial Subordinate Judge, Delhi in Suit No. 264 of 1956 under Order XXXVII, C.P.C.

facts.text: Defendants Santosh Kumar and Northern General Agencies granted special leave to appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants, Santosh Kumar and the Northern General Agencies, were granted special leave to appeal.

facts.text: Plaintiff filed suit based on cheque for Rs. 60,000 drawn by defendants in favour of plaintiff, which was dishonoured on presentation to the Bank.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff filed the suit out of which the 1213 appeal arises on the basis of a cheque for Rs. 60,000 drawn by the defendants in favour of the plaintiff and which, on presentation to the Bank, was dishonoured.

facts.text: Defendants applied for leave to defend the suit under rule 3 of Order XXXVII.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was filed in the Court of the Commercial Subordinate Judge, Delhi, under 0. XXXVII of the Code of Civil Procedure. The defendants applied for leave to defend the suit under r. 3 of that Order.

facts.text: Trial Judge held that defence raises a triable issue.

anchor.surface_text: The learned trial Judge held that the defence raised by the defendants raises a triable issue, but he went on to hold that the defendants have number placed anything on the file to show that the defence was a bona fide one.

facts.text: Trial Judge permitted defendants to defend suit on condition of giving security for suit amount and costs.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, he permitted the defendants to appear and defend the suit on the companydition of their giving security to the extent of the suit amount and the companyts of the suit.

facts.text: Defendants applied for review in trial court and failed.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants applied for a review but failed.

facts.text: Defendants applied under Article 227 to Delhi Circuit Bench of Punjab High Court and failed.

anchor.surface_text: They then applied under Art. 227 of the Constitution to the Delhi Circuit Bench of the Punjab High Court and failed again.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave under Article 136.

anchor.surface_text: As a result, they applied here under Art. 136 and were granted special leave.

facts.text: Defendants admitted execution of the cheque.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants admitted execution of the cheque but pleaded that it was only given as companylateral security

facts.text: Defendants pleaded cheque given as collateral security for price of goods supplied by plaintiff to defendants.

anchor.surface_text: but pleaded that it was only given as companylateral security for the price of goods which the plaintiff supplied to the defendants.

facts.text: Defendants claimed goods were paid for by cash payments and other cheques.

anchor.surface_text: They said that those goods were paid for by cash payments made from time to time and by other cheques and that therefore the cheque in suit had served its end

facts.text: Defendants set out exact dates and numbers of cheques for payments.

anchor.surface_text: They set out the exact dates on which, according to them, the payments had been made and gave the numbers of the cheques.

facts.text: Trial Judge held defence not backed by documents, hence not bona fide.

anchor.surface_text: But he held that it was number enough for the defendants to back up their assertions with an affidavit they should also have produced writings and documents which they said were in their possession

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on February 5, 1958 by BOSE J.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. February 5. The following Judgment of the Court was delivered by BOSE J.-

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside orders of High Court and trial Judge, remanded case for trial.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is allowed. We set aside the orders of the High Court and the learned trial Judge and remand the case to the first Court for trial of the issues raised by the defendants.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that trial Judge erred in requiring documents before granting leave to defend.

anchor.surface_text: We find it difficult to see how a defence that, on the face of it, is clear becomes vague simply because the evidence by which it is to be proved is number brought on file at the time the defence is put in.

facts.text: Supreme Court held defence raises triable issue and leave should be unconditional.

facts.text: Defendants pleaded cheque should be returned as it had served its end after payments.

anchor.surface_text: and that therefore the cheque in suit had served its end and should number be returned.

issues.text: Whether the defence raised by the defendants raises a triable issue

The learned trial Judge held that the defence raised by the defendants raises a triable issue, but he went on to hold that the defendants have number placed anything on the file to show that the defence was a bona fide one. Accordingly, he permitted the defendants

issues.text: Whether the discretion conferred by Order XXXVII Rule 3(2) CPC is unfettered

anchor.surface_text: enlarged in another direction by r. 3 2  which says that Leave to defend may be given unconditionally or subject to such terms as to payment into Court, giving security, framing and recording issues or otherwise as the Court thinks fit. The learned counsel for the plaintiff argues that the discretion so conferred by r. 3 2  is unfettered

issues.text: Whether leave to defend must be granted unconditionally when a triable issue is raised

anchor.surface_text: The decision most frequently referred to is a decision of the House of Lords in England where a similar rule prevails. It is Jacobs v. Booths Distillery Company  1 . Judgment was delivered in 1901. Their Lordships said that whenever the defence raises a triable issue, leave must be given, and later cases say that when that is the case it must be given unconditionally, otherwise the leave may be illusory.

issues.text: Whether defendants must produce documents at the affidavit stage to show bona fide defence for leave to defend

anchor.surface_text: But he held that it was number enough for the defendants to back up their assertions with an affidavit they should also have produced writings and documents which they said were in their possession I.L.R. 1950 Mad. 251. 1217 and which they asserted would prove that the cheques and payments referred to in their defence were given in payment of the cheque in suit and he said- In the absence of those documents, the defence of the defendants seems to be vague consisting of indefinite assertions

issues.text: Whether the trial court's discretion to impose conditions was exercised judicially in consonance with natural justice

anchor.surface_text: Next, there must be ever present to the mind the fact that our laws of procedure are grounded on a principle of natural justice which requires that men should number be condemned unheard, that decisions should number be reached behind their backs, that proceedings that affect their lives and property should number continue in their absence and that they should number be precluded from participating in them. Of course, there must be exceptions... Applied to the present case, these observations mean that though the Court is given a discretion it must be exercised along judicial lines, and that in turn means, in consonance with the principles of natural justice

issues.text: Whether there is a failure of justice warranting interference under Article 136

anchor.surface_text: But if the 1218 discretion is exercised arbitrarily, or is based on a mis- understanding of the principles that govern its exercise, then interference is called for if there has been a resultant failure of justice. As we have said, the only ground given for concluding that the defence is number bona fide is that the defendant did number prove his assertions before he was allowed to put in his defence and there is an obvious failure of justice if judgment is entered against a man who, if he is allowed to prove his case, cannot but succeed.

arguments.claim: The discretion conferred by Order XXXVII Rule 3(2) CPC is unfettered and no appeal lies against its exercise unless there is grave miscarriage of justice or flagrant violation of law

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the plaintiff argues that the discretion so conferred by r. 3 2  is unfettered and that as the discretion has been exercised by the learned trial Judge, no appeal can lie against it unless there is a grave miscarriage of justice or flagrant violation of law and he quotes D. N. Banerji v. P.R. Mukherjee  1  and Waryam Singh v. Amarnath  2 .

court_response_anchor.surface_text: r. 2 2  narrowed down by r. 3 1  than it is again enlarged in another direction by r. 3 2  which says that Leave to defend may be given unconditional

arguments.court_reasoning: Discretion must be exercised judicially in consonance with natural justice and principles governing procedure; not unfettered as procedure is to facilitate justice

anchor.surface_text: The learned trial Judge held that the defence raised by the defendants raises a triable issue, but he went on to hold that the defendants have not placed anything on the file to show that the defence was a bona fide one. Accordingly, he permitted the defendants to appear and defend the suit on the condition of their giving security to the extent of the suit amount and the costs of the suit.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants admitted execution of the cheque but pleaded that it was only given as collateral security for the price of goods which the plaintiff supplied to the defendants. They said that those goods were paid for by cash payments made from time to time and by other cheques and that therefore the cheque in suit had served its end and should not be returned. They set out the exact dates

arguments.court_reasoning: Conditions only if defence not bona fide or to ensure speedy trial; not for good defence

arguments.claim: If defence not bona fide court can impose conditions instead of refusing leave

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the plaintiff-respondent relied on Gopala Rao v. Subba Rao  5 , Manohar Lal v. Nanhe Mal  6 , and Shib Karan Das v. Mohammed Sadiq  7 . All that we need say about them is that if the Court is of opinion that the defence is not bona fide, then it can impose conditions and is not tied down to refusing leave to defend.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ple of natural justice which requires that men should number be companydemned unheard, that decisions should number be reached behind their backs, tha

arguments.court_reasoning: Agree court has this course open but cannot conclude not bona fide arbitrarily; must follow judicial rules

arguments.claim: Whenever defence raises triable issue leave to defend must be given unconditionally

anchor.surface_text: Their Lordships said that whenever the defence raises a triable issue, leave must be given, and later cases say that when that is the case it must be given unconditionally, otherwise the leave may be illusory. See, for example, Powszechny Bank Zwiazkowy W. Polsce v. Paros  2 , in England and Sundaram Chettiar v. Valli Ammal  3  in India.

arguments.claim: Discretion under Order XXXVII Rule 3(2) not unfettered; must be exercised judicially in consonance with natural justice

anchor.surface_text: Now what we are examining here are laws of procedure... Applied to the present case, these observations mean that though the Court is given a discretion it must be exercised along judicial lines, and that in turn means, in consonance with the principles of natural justice that form the foundations of our laws.

arguments.claim: Procedural rules grounded on natural justice; to be construed to facilitate justice not frustrate it

anchor.surface_text: Next, there must be ever present to the mind the fact that our laws of procedure are grounded on a principle of natural justice which requires that men should not be condemned unheard... our laws of procedure should be construed, wherever that is reasonably possible, in the light of that principle.

arguments.claim: Order XXXVII Rule 3(1) obligatorily grants leave if affidavit discloses facts requiring proof of consideration or sufficient facts

anchor.surface_text: But the rigour of that is softened by r. 3 1  which makes it obligatory on the Court to grant leave when the conditions set out there are fulfilled. Clause  1  runs- The Court shall, upon application by the defendant, give leave to appear and to defend the suit, upon affidavits which disclose such facts as would make it incumbent on the holder to prove consideration, or such other facts as the Court may deem sufficient to support the application.

arguments.claim: Test for leave is whether defence raises real issue not sham; if facts alleged proved would be good defence

anchor.surface_text: In general, therefore, the test is to see whether the defence raises a real issue and not a sham one, in the sense that, if the facts alleged by the defendant are established, there would be a good, or even a plausible, defence on those facts.

arguments.claim: No need to produce documents or evidence at affidavit stage for leave to defend; only assess if alleged facts if proved good defence

anchor.surface_text: But he held that it was not enough for the defendants to back up their assertions with an affidavit they should also have produced writings and documents... We find it difficult to see how a defence that, on the face of it, is clear becomes vague simply because the evidence by which it is to be proved is not brought on file at the time the defence is put in.

arguments.claim: Conditions on leave only if reason to believe defendant prolonging litigation; not merely for lack of evidence at application stage

anchor.surface_text: The learned High Court Judge is also in error... As we have explained, the power to impose conditions is only there to ensure that there will be a speedy trial. If there is reason to believe that the defendant is trying to prolong the litigation and evade a speedy trial, then conditions can be imposed.

arguments.claim: Interference under Article 136 warranted if discretion exercised arbitrarily or on misunderstanding of principles causing failure of justice

anchor.surface_text: But if the discretion is exercised arbitrarily, or is based on a mis- understanding of the principles that govern its exercise, then interference is called for if there has been a resultant failure of justice. As we have said, the only ground given for concluding that the defence is not bona fide is that the defendant did not prove his assertions before he was allowed to put in his defence

arguments.claim: Object of Order XXXVII is to prevent unnecessary prolongation by frivolous defences in commercial suits

anchor.surface_text: Taken by and large, the object is to see that the defendant does not unnecessarily prolong the litigation and prevent the plaintiff from obtaining an early decree by raising untenable and frivolous defences in a class of cases where speedy decisions are desirable in the interests of trade and commerce.

holdings.text: The defence raised by the defendants raises a triable issue warranting unconditional leave to defend.

anchor.surface_text: This at once raised an issue of fact, the truth and good faith of which could only be tested by going into the evidence and, as we have pointed out, the learned trial Judge held that this defence did raise a triable issue.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Defendants' affidavit specifies exact dates and cheque numbers for alleged payments; if proved, constitutes plausible defence; trial judge accepted but erred in conditioning.

holdings.text: The discretion conferred by Order XXXVII Rule 3(2) CPC is not unfettered but must be exercised judicially in consonance with natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: Applied to the present case, these observations mean that though the Court is given a discretion it must be exercised along judicial lines, and that in turn means, in consonance with the principles of natural justice that form the foundations of our laws.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural laws grounded in natural justice (audi alteram partem); discretion not arbitrary; cites Sangram Singh v. Election Tribunal for purposive interpretation.

holdings.text: Leave to defend must be granted unconditionally where the defence raises a triable issue.

anchor.surface_text: Their Lordships said that whenever the defence raises a triable issue, leave must be given, and later cases say that when that is the case it must be given unconditionally, otherwise the leave may be illusory.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopts House of Lords in Jacobs v. Booths Distillery and Indian/English cases; conditional leave renders right illusory.

holdings.text: Defendants need not produce documents or evidence at the affidavit stage to obtain leave to defend; assessment based on pleaded facts alone.

anchor.surface_text: We find it difficult to see how a defence that, on the face of it, is clear becomes vague simply because the evidence by which it is to be proved is not brought on file at the time the defence is put in.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proof stage follows leave grant; at application, only check if alleged facts if proved afford good defence; trial judge erred in requiring documents prematurely.

holdings.text: Trial court's imposition of security condition was not in consonance with natural justice as defence was bona fide and triable.

anchor.surface_text: This is a surprising conclusion. The facts given in the affidavit are clear and precise, the defence could hardly have been clearer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No basis for deeming not bona fide absent evidence of sham; conditions only for non-bona fide defences or delay prevention; violates hear both sides.

holdings.text: Interference under Article 136 warranted due to arbitrary exercise of discretion causing failure of justice.

anchor.surface_text: But if the discretion is exercised arbitrarily, or is based on a mis-understanding of the principles that govern its exercise, then interference is called for if there has been a resultant failure of justice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Misunderstanding of leave principles; defendant precluded from trial despite plausible defence; results in judgment without hearing.

holdings.text: Conditions on leave to defend permissible only if defence not bona fide or to ensure speedy trial by preventing prolongation.

anchor.surface_text: As we have explained, the power to impose conditions is only there to ensure that there will be a speedy trial. If there is reason to believe that the defendant is trying to prolong the litigation and evade a speedy trial, then conditions can be imposed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Object of Order XXXVII is speedy commercial justice; conditions not for valid defences; High Court erred in upholding for good defence.

holdings.text: Appeal allowed; orders of High Court and trial court set aside; case remanded for trial on merits.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is allowed. We set aside the orders of the High Court and the learned trial Judge and remand the case to the first Court for trial of the issues raised by the defendants.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative errors in refusing unconditional leave necessitate full trial.
